item.title: [Saputara, Gujarat, India] Discovering the Little Treasures of a Small Hill Station
item.description:
A journey alongÂ winding roads through a verdant forest took usÂ toÂ the small hill station of Saputara.Â We headed to this little town in the Dang district of South Gujarat after a greatÂ break in Silvassa. The route through the Vansda National Park was scenic and more beautiful than we had imagined.

En route to Saputara, Gujarat.

At Saputara, we reveled inÂ the simple pleasures of a small town where you can walk to (almost) any destination. As we discoveredÂ the little treasures of the hill town, theÂ vividÂ colors made a big impression on us.

View from the ropeway. Saputara, Gujarat, India.

Shades of Blue atÂ the Lake:
The Saputara Lake is the heart of the town. The water body can be viewed from several locations. After a laid-backÂ morning routine, weÂ got some exerciseÂ by rentingÂ a paddle boat at the lake. Junior was thrilled to play the role of the captain. Now, his parents were “officially” under his command.

Blue. Saputara Lake, Gujarat, India

Vibrance ofÂ Green inÂ the Pretty Gardens:
If green is your color, head to theÂ Lake Garden, which also has a children’s park. Take a picnic basket along, if you’d like.Â The Nageshwar Mahadev temple nearby is a quiet place with a pretty view of the lake.
For a touch of other colors, visit the Step Garden. The steps are adorned with flowers in a host of colors.

Green (and some blue!) At the Lake Garden. Saputara, Gujarat, India.

MagicÂ of Red and White at the Museum:

TheÂ Saputara Tribal Museum showcases the life and culture of the numerous tribal communities in the region. The museum was larger than we had expected, and it had severalÂ interesting displays. The highlight is theÂ beautiful Warli Art collection. Junior and B were engaged in animated conversation as they discussedÂ the details of every Warli painting. 

  <p class="wp-caption-text">
    Red and White in Warli Art. Saputara, Gujarat, India.
  </p>
</div>

HuesÂ ofÂ CrimsonÂ andÂ Orange in the Sky:
I’mÂ always awe-struckÂ byÂ the marvelousÂ hues in the skyÂ at sunrise and sunset. My favorite sceneÂ at Saputara was the descent of the sun.
Head to theÂ Sunrise Point near the Jain temple, and gaze at the spectacular painting in the sky.Â Or take the ropeway to the Sunset Viewpoint. And, at the end of the day, watch the sky light up in myriad tinges of crimson and orange.

Colors on the horizon. Saputara, Gujarat, India.

Where would you go in Saputara? Which color would you choose?

item.title: [Indore, India] Flavors of Indore
item.description:
In 2015, we embarked on our first trip to the geographical heart of India, Madhya Pradesh (MP). Our itinerary featured threeÂ destinations in theÂ Malwa region of MP: Mandu (Mandav), Indore, and Maheshwar.

 

A Blend of Architectures. Lalbagh Palace, Indore, India

 

During our brief stay at Indore, we took the foodie route and stopped byÂ some of the city’s popular eating joints. If you ask our taste buds, it was completely worth the time!

We also escaped to a couple of green hideouts, away from the bustle of the large city. AsÂ we drove around the busy neighborhoodsÂ and passedÂ the Rajwada area and the Chhatris on the Khan river banks, we decided to head to the parks in Indore. In the tussle between historical places of interest and green spaces, the latter won our favor (well, we did manage to check outÂ the Lalbagh Palace).

 

Royal BeginningÂ at the Lalbagh Palace:

For a brief glimpse of history, we visited the Lalbagh Palace. This former residence of the Holkar dynasty is a blend of various architectures. The lavish interiors and ornate architecture gave us glimpses into the royal life of the Holkars. For a nominal fee, one can enterÂ the palace and view the numerous rooms,Â paintings, and elaborate decor.

Lalbagh Palace, Indore, India

Look closely. Lalbagh Palace, Indore, India

 

A SunnyÂ Morning at the Indore Zoo:

Kamla Nehru Zoo or Indore ZooÂ is located in the Navlakha area of the city. We were among the first visitors of the day and loved the peace and quiet in the zoo.

As we walked around, the emus huddled together while a baby hippo snuggled up against mommy hippo. Crocodiles basked in the sun and the tigers paced up and down in their enclosures.Â A kids’ play area with equipment made from unused tires was a big attraction for Junior. The little monkey of our family had a wonderfulÂ time swinging and climbing in the playground.

Welcome! Indore Zoo, India

 

Basking in the sun. Indore Zoo, India

Setting the pace. Indore Zoo, India

 

Green and Blue at Pipliyapala Regional Park:

The Pipliyapala Regional Park (Atal Bihari Vajpayee Regional Park) was a pleasant surprise. This 100 acre park in the outskirts of the city is a quick and refreshing getaway.

The urban green space on the banks of the Pipliyapala Lake has all the necessary features of a popular attraction. Landscaped gardens, prettyÂ shades of green, various hues of blue, vast open spaces, paved walking paths, and, of course, a few food stalls and boating in the lake! ðŸ™‚

We strolled along (all) the paths, crossed (almost all) the bridges over the canal, and spotted many water birds. Red-wattled lapwings ruled the roost, while a few cormorants and egrets stood silently at the water’s edge. The “mist fountains” on the bridges added some jazz to the serene setting.

Junior had a fun time winding his way through the maze (although he found his way out very easily and grumbled a little about how simple it was… I guess he’s growing up!)

A Mughal Garden, a French Garden, and a lovely open air amphitheater (my favorite!) complete the picture.

As the sun went down, the lights in the park came on and added a special effect.

Pipliyapala Regional Park, Indore, India

Pretty Bridges. Pipliyapala Regional Park, Indore, India

Lake-watching. Pipliyapala Regional Park, Indore, India

And some bird-watching. Red wattled lapwing, Pipliyapala Regional Park, Indore, India

 

Indulging our Taste Buds:

After all that I had read about the food scene in Indore, my taste buds were yearning for those delicious treats. So, off we went on our foodie route.

We binged on khopra patties, kachori, shikanji and kesar lassi at Vijay Chaat House in Chappan (56) Dukaan. Head forÂ the long line of eateries in this narrow lane. Locals and visitors flock to this areaÂ in the evenings. Visit _56 Dukaan_Â to find out what the noise (and food) is all aboutÂ (you will not regret it!).

Also on our agenda (umm.. menu) were parathas and malpua at Apna Sweets. Another time, there was space forÂ grilled sandwiches and cold coffee at a local cafe. The famous Indori Poha was on our breakfast menu. And lastly, we could not leave the cityÂ without buying the popular Khatta Meetha snackÂ from Indore.

 

Treat your taste buds. Vijay Chaat House, Indore, India

item.title: [Maheshwar, India] A Trip to Maheshwar: On the Banks of the Narmada
item.description:
In 2015, we embarked on our first trip to the geographical heart of India, Madhya Pradesh (MP). Our itinerary featured threeÂ destinations in theÂ Malwa region of MP: Mandu (Mandav), Indore, and Maheshwar.

The Temples and Ghat along the River Narmada. Maheshwar, Madhya Pradesh, India

Picturesque river views, beautiful temples, a majestic fort, a serene boat ride, and a long meditative stroll along the riverside ghats. Maheshwar was the perfect place to end our vacation. Home to the famous Maheshwari handloom saris and capital of the brave queen, Ahilyabai Holkar, this small town on the banks of the river Narmada left an indelible impression on my heart.

In the eighteenth century, Queen Ahilyabai HolkarÂ ruled from Maheshwar.Â InÂ 1818, Indore was chosen as the capital of the Holkar dynasty. Even today, AhilyabaiÂ is revered in the town of Maheshwar.

The Majestic Fort of a BraveÂ Queen
The fort stands tall on the banks of the river Narmada. ThisÂ majestic fort is testimony toÂ the storyÂ of the greatÂ queen, Ahilyabai Holkar, and her impressive reign over the Indore state. A statue of the Queen is located at the entrance to the fort. Inside, a small temple and a museum are open to visitors. From the fort, we viewed the river Narmada below, flowingÂ along peacefully on its journey toward the Arabian Sea.
Only a part of the fort is accessible to all visitors. The otherÂ part of the fort premises has been converted into a heritage hotel.

Queen Ahilyabai Holkar. Maheshwar Fort, Madhya Pradesh

Exquisite Temples: Stories from Mythology and History
The town of Maheshwar is said to have been mentioned in the Ramayana and Mahabharata with the name ‘Mahishmati’.
KingÂ Sahastrarjun fought and defeated an angry Ravana here. Then, he placed ten lamps on Ravana’s heads and one lamp on his hand. The detailed story is available here.Â We visited the Sahastrarjun temple near the fort. Even today, eleven lamps are lit in the temple to commemorate the event.
Next, we paid our respects to Lord Shiva atÂ theÂ Rajarajeshwar and Kashivishwanath temples nearby.

Temples of Maheshwar. Madhya Pradesh, India

As we proceededÂ from the fort towardÂ the ghat, two exquisite temples with beautiful sculptures captured our attention. The sculptures and intricate designs here are a sight to behold. Time came to a standstill as we admired these works of art. Suddenly, we were interrupted by noisy schoolchildren. Oh well, they moved on in a few minutes. And then, it was quiet again. Junior was quite enthusiastic about observing the sculptures in detail. We walkedÂ from one wall to another, one structureÂ to another, up a flight of steps, and down another. So much to see, so much to appreciate.

Temples of Maheshwar. Madhya Pradesh, India 

<p class="wp-caption-text">
  Temples of Maheshwar. Madhya Pradesh, India
</p>

We are Family! Maheshwar Temple Complex, Madhya Pradesh, India 

<p class="wp-caption-text">
  Craftsmanship on Display. Maheshwar Temple Complex, Madhya Pradesh, India
</p>


<p class="wp-caption-text">
  Look who’s here! Maheshwar Temple Complex, Madhya Pradesh, India
</p>

Tranquil Ghat Along the Narmada: Prayer, Reflection, and Meditation
Just before sundown, we strolledÂ along the serene Ahilyabai ghats, a place that is considered to resemble a ‘mini-Varanasi’.
The clean ghats are dotted with small Shiva idols and accompanying Nandi statues. No flurry of activity or loud noise here. A man was deeply engaged in prayer. Another rowed his boat gently along the Narmada. The sun began its descent toward the horizon. A few tourists returned from their journeyÂ to the Baneshwar temple on a small island. We gazed up at the fort that loomed in the background. And then, we turned our attention to the hues of crimson in the sky. The numerous temples rose up above the ghats. Each monument told a tale. Each structure breathed history. All we did was pause and listen.

Shiva and Nandi. Ghat along the Narmada, Maheshwar, Madhya Pradesh, India 

<p class="wp-caption-text">
  Sunset and Tranquil Moments at the Ghat. Maheshwar, Madhya Pradesh, India
</p>

Movie Magic:

Maheshwar has been a popular filming locationÂ in the Indian movie industry. Take a look at the pictures in this blog post and try toÂ guess whichÂ movies and songs have been shot here.

Useful Information:
– Accommodation: The MPTDC Narmada Retreat, on the banks of the river, offers comfortable accommodation. It has spacious rooms, a vast garden and aÂ children’s play area.
– Eating: The restaurant at MPTDC Narmada RetreatÂ and Laboos Cafe, which is located betweenÂ the ghats andÂ the fort entrance.
– Shopping: Buy Maheshwari handloom saris at the outlets in the town.

– Other activities: Visitors can enjoyÂ aÂ boat ride in the river.

item.title: [Mandu, India] A Trip to Mandu: Where History Comes Alive â€“ II
item.description:
This year, we embarked on our first trip to the geographical heart of India, Madhya Pradesh (MP). Our itinerary featured threeÂ destinations in theÂ Malwa region of MP: Mandu (Mandav), Indore, and Maheshwar.

Domes and more (domes). Jami Masjid, Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh

Our visit to the charming town of Mandu took us back in time… through centuries of rule by various dynasties. As power changed hands severalÂ times (from the Parmars to the Khiljis), each dynasty left behind an imprint: of monumentsÂ andÂ stories. And theÂ treasure trove of stories comes alive in the monuments of Mandu.

If you haven’t already read the first part of this account of Mandu, here it is.

And now, let’s move on toÂ the second part of the story.

 

The Magnificence of the Central Village Group:Â Jami Masjid and Hoshang Shah’s Tomb

As we enteredÂ the town center, a splendid monument with aÂ largeÂ number of domes rose majestically.Â ThisÂ edifice, the Jami Masjid,Â impressesÂ the visitor with its magnificence.

The grand Jami Masjid has been inspired by the Great Mosque of Damascus. ItsÂ sublime beauty is highlighted by theÂ numerousÂ domes, pillars, and arches. A vast courtyard in the premises was the perfect place for us to pause for a while, and soak in the solemnity and grandeur of the architecture.

The magnificent Jami Masjid. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh.

Arches galore. Jami Masjid, Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh

 

A path from the Jami Masjid led usÂ to another architectural gem, Hoshang Shah’s Tomb. This marble structure is a symbol of Afghan architecture. The monument is believed to have been the inspiration for Shah Jahan’s Taj Mahal.

On one side of the mausoleum, in the same complex, is a Dharamshala, built in typical Hindu style. We walked along the path, gazing at the lovely designs of the pillars and brackets. The contrast of the Hindu and Afghan architectural styles, in the same compound, left us wondering about history and its many paradoxes.

Hoshang Shah’s Tomb. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh

Hoshang Shah’s Tomb. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh

Pillars of the Dharamshala. Near Hoshang Shah’s Tomb, Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh.

 

Walk, Stroll, Explore Other Monuments

In Mandu, it is a good idea to take an unhurried stroll around the town and spot the “hidden” ruins and edifices. I loved looking out for the domes in the distance, ruined monuments hiddenÂ byÂ trees,Â and picturesqueÂ little ponds in greenÂ surroundings.

A pond. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh.

Hidden Domes. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh.

 

Go where the path leads. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh.

 

Unique Nilkanth Temple and Palace

It was time to bid adieu to Mandu. As we headed out of town, there was one last place to visit.Â Situated at the edge of a cliff, overlooking a gorge, is a holy Shiva shrine. We descended a flight of stairs to reach the Nilkanth Temple and Palace complex.

A tranquil pond and a small stream flowing from it mark the entrance to the shrine. The uniqueness of this Hindu temple lies in the Islamic architecture of the structure around the shrine. The edifice, constructed by a Mughal governor for Akbar’s Hindu wife, has Persian inscriptions.

We spent some time enjoying the serenity of the location and the pretty views of the gorge. ItÂ was the perfect way to bid farewell to the fortress town of Mandu.

Nilkanth Temple and Palace. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh.

View from Nilkanth Temple. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh.

 

Useful Info:

– How to reachÂ Mandu: We followed the NH3 (from Dhule toward Indore), and turned left immediately after ‘Palash Resort’ on the highway. A sign indicating the direction to Mandu was visible here.

– Where to stay: Madhya Pradesh TourismÂ offers a couple of options – Malwa Retreat and Malwa Resort.

item.description:
This year, we embarked on our first trip to the geographical heart of India, Madhya Pradesh (MP). Our itinerary featured threeÂ destinations in theÂ Malwa region of MP: Mandu (Mandav), Indore, and Maheshwar.

 

Monuments of Mandu. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh

ManduÂ (also known as Mandav or Mandavgad) is strategically located at a height of about 2000 feet in the Vindhya ranges. This formerly fortified town with its beautiful monuments transported us back in time. History comes alive at Mandu. From the panoramic vistasÂ atop Roopmati Pavilion to theÂ intricate waterways and reservoirs in the Royal Enclave complex,Â the imprints of splendor and history are etched everywhere!Â The landscape,Â dominated byÂ numerousÂ arches and domes, is dotted with several lakes and ponds.

StrollÂ around the town and discover itsÂ marvels. ConcealedÂ behind the trees, peering out from the overgrown grass, just behindÂ the corner – is a hidden treasure.

The absence of crowds (at some locations, we were the only visitors! :)) made it a thoroughlyÂ enjoyable experience for us.

 

Roopmati Pavilion and Baz Bahadur’s Palace (Rewa Kund Group): AÂ Legendary Love Story

WeÂ gazed at the spectacular views from the Roopmati Pavilion and imagined the queen looking out from this point, admiring the Nimar valley below and the River Narmada flowing through it. Baz Bahadur, the last Sultan of Malwa, was charmed byÂ Roopmati’s beauty and melodious voice. He loved her dearly and brought her to Mandu. Unfortunately, their romantic tale was short-lived and ended in tragedy caused by the advance of the Mughal army.

 

Roopmati Pavilion, Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh

Arches at Roopmati Pavilion. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh, India

Baz Bahadur’s Palace is adorned with beautiful arches and a lovely courtyard. From here,Â one can admire the surrounding countryside and catch a glimpse of the Roopmati Pavilion on the hilltop.

We also briefly haltedÂ at the Rewa Kund, aÂ pond that was built as a reservoir for supplying water.

 

Baz Bahadur’s Palace. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh, India

Rewa Kund. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh, India

 

TheÂ Grandeur and BeautyÂ of the Royal Enclave Group (Shahi Mahal Complex)

The Royal Enclave group is a visual treat. We headed to this complex late in the afternoon, and hoped to witness a pretty sunset.

The grand Jahaz Mahal (Ship Palace) was a fantastic place to begin our exploration. Situated on a narrow strip of landÂ between two ponds (Munj Talao and Kapur Talao), this two-storeyed structure has a fascinating design. Junior, our ship commander, was at the helm, and he led the way. We truly enjoyed the ride :). This palace is believed to have been constructedÂ by Sultan Ghiyas-ud-din Khilji for his harem.

 

 

Jahaz Mahal. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh, India

Jahaz Mahal. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh, India

Hindola Mahal. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh, India

Arches at Hindola Mahal. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh, India

 

The unique Hindola Mahal (Swinging Palace) is another beautiful edifice. We discussed the design ofÂ its sloping walls and marveledÂ at the intricate and detailedÂ workÂ in stone.

Beyond the Hindola Mahal, numerousÂ partially ruined buildings and structures dot the area. Among theÂ architectural wondersÂ here areÂ the Champa Baoli (a big well), a Hamam, several fountains, and waterways. Come here to learn about aÂ water supplyÂ and managementÂ system (with temperature control!) designed in the olden days.

Monuments. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh, India

Hamam. Mandu (Mandav), Madhya Pradesh, India

At the end of the day, we spottedÂ a seat near the Kapur Talao, facing the grand Jahaz Mahal. Comfortably seatedÂ on the bench, we watched the sun settingÂ gradually.Â The varied hues in the sky providedÂ a perfect backdrop to the visual splendor of theÂ palace complex.
